div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,672] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels.
div.p: GRAND HOTEL, HELOUAN.-- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

HOTEL DES BAINS.-- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 45. Attached to the above hotels and specially for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Gold House in the desert.
SULPHUR BATH ESTABLISHMENT.-- Shulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masse in and Masseuseu Eve y modern improvement.

div.head: THE GERMAN ELECTIONS.
div.p: Our telegrams state that the most important election ever held in Germany has resulted in favour of the Kaiser and a Government majority seems now certain. The issue was of enormous importance, for the Germans had to choose between two alternatives, whether the Hohenzollern dynasty was to dictate the policy of the Empire without asking popular advice, or whether the people were to have & larger share of self government and a more final control of their own taxation. The German people, as the results of the elections show, have decided that they wish to be governed directly by the Emperor and his representatives in preference to exercising themselves a controlling influence over their own destiny Heine says somewhere that an Englishman loves liberty steadily as he loves his lawful wife, a Frenchman passionately as a mistress, but a German's love of liberty is as a man's love for his grandmother.

The truth of this comparison is seen in these elections. The German people are just awakening to self-consciousness, and with it to an intense desire for a larger share in the control of administration. They think that if colonial policy costs money, they ought to have an equal vote with their Sovereign in colonial policy. The last vote of the late Reichstag directly impaired the prerogative implied in the Kaiser's claim to be War-Lord, for through it he ceased to be able to keep sufficient troops in his South-West African possessions, where war is actually raging. The Emperor therefore, in his owh opinion, had the only alternative of

asking his people whether they really meant him to give way before the opposition of his dark subjects in South Africa. He determined on a bold course, and by dissolving the Reichstag called on the people of Germany to stultify the decision and authority of their representative body. The Kaiser's action clearly showed the German people thta he was ready to disallow the authority of the Reichstag, and that it was the duty of his subjects to simply obey and give him the means which he thinks his military policy requires. The German people have replied the Emperor's challenge with all due sub missiveness and have given him a majority instead of returning a Reichstag which would demand full control over its own finances. In other words, they havo deliberately thrown away their rights to a larger share of self government for the sake of the Kaiser's Wel Politik. The issue was clearly put before the German people, and neither the Emperor nor his opponents endeavoured to minimise the momentous nature of the struggle.

Herr Maximilian Harden, in his weekly review, "Die Zukunft," describing the issues before the German people in the elections, said:— "We want to rule ourselves as well and as conscientiously as we can. The German may be proud of much that his country has produced. The German peasant, artisan, soldier, and business man can hold his own with any. There is great activity among the arts, in industry, in banking, in commerce, and at least as much is accomplished as in other countries and with scanty means. . . . But we are badly governed, and the most important State institutions no longer satisfy the demands of the times. In international politics we Can do nothing considerable for years to come, thanks partly to Uncle Edward and partly to our own fault. . . . Things cannot possibly go worse than they have under a Hohenlohe or a Bulow ; our next aim must be to assure Parliamentary government." These opinions were re-echoed throughout all the Liberal and Socialist Press of the Fatherland. The appeals on the other side were no less vigorous The Conservative "Reichsbote ''(Berlin, Jan. 8)says :—"A determining fight has begun for the maintenance of our national honour, for the future, even for the very existence, of the Empire. The German people must now prove whether they can keep sacred the hardly won fruits of 1870, or whether egotism and political and national indifference have consumed the springs of life of the German nation, and will now deliver the latter over to the dominion of elements owning no Fatherland. ... If the anti-national parties are returned to the Reichstag in undiminished force, this will be the signal for joint action by Germany's foes ; it will be the prelude to a great struggle for the annihilation of everything German, which has for years been the dream of the Slav, Romanic, and Anglo-Saxon worlds. . . . During the past few years the German Empire has forfeited much of its former prestige, a fact which is due partly to want of firmness on the part of the Government, but chiefly to the deplorable attitude assumed by our Imperial Parliament. The security of the Empire demands imperatively that our national prestige abroad shall not suffer further. The 25th of January decides. If on that day victory is with those who on Dec. 13 refused to grant a vote for South-West Africa, if victory is with Ultramontanism, which is inimical to the Empire, the time will have come when our enemies will believe the moment for revenge has arrived. We shall then in a very short time hear the rattle of musketry in the Vosges; Polish hordes will carry fire and sword through the East of the Empire, and the thunder of the 'Dreadnought's' guns will roar off the German emporium of Hamburg. We shall have peace only if Germany is united and strong."

From a purely impartial view of the election results it is clear that, despite the great progress of the Socialist Party during the last few years, the masses of the German people are still unconscious of the elements of political emancipation and prefer to be governed by an autocrat rather than by parliamentary principles such as prevail in England. After all, their decision may be politically a sound one, but that is for the historians of the future to decide.

Although no definite decision has been arrived at with regard to the opening of the next Reichstag, it is believed in trustworthy quarters that the opening ceremony will take place either on February 14 or February 19. It is not likely that the Reichstag will sit longer than four months at the most. Its work will consist in bringing forward and voting upon the supplementary credits, the next Budget, the projected law with regard to professional societies, and perhaps, if necessary, one or other of the treaties of commerce which have been left in abeyance for the time. All other measures will be postponed until the Session of next autumn.
Upper Egypt Hotels.
Our readers will find on page 6 particulars of the new issue of shares in the Upper Egypt Hotels Company.
Heliopolis Oasis.
It is stated that a French syndicate has purchased 60,000 metres of land at Heliopolis Oasis at 20 francs per metre.
A Reoord
The Khedivial Mail S.S. Osmanieh arrived at Alexandria at 8 a.m. to-day after a twenty- three hours' voyage from the Pi aens.
Quarantine In Turkey.
A telegram from Constantinople states that the quarantine measures against Smyrna have been removed, while arrivals from Suez are subjected to a medical examination.
Agricultural Show.
H.H. the Khedive has kindly consented to open the Agricultural Show at Cairo on February, 28. The Show will thus be held on February 28, March 1, 2. 3, and 4, instead of the dates previously fixed.
Cairo Scientific Society.

A meeting of the society will take place at the School of Medicine at 4,30 p.m. on Thursday, 31st inst. A paper will be read on "Heredity" by Mr. W. L. Balls, and Mr. B.H. Wade will exhibit an instrument for the field determination of longitude.
Coal Imports.

For the year to January 24 the total import of coal at Alexandria was 41,568 tons, made up as follows : Welsh, 20,896 ; Newcastle, 12,367; Sootch, 1,510 ; Yorkshire, 3 798 ; other qualities 3,497. The total fir the same period last year was 52,670 tons.
Burning a Bowab.

On Saturday night a Greek resident of Alexandria found a bowab asleep in a building in El Ibrahim-etreet. He poured petroleum over the unconcious bowab awd then set him slight, with the result that he was burned to death. The murderer was arrested by the police, and handed over to the Hellenic consular authorities
Comptoir Financier

We learn that the Comptoir Financier has acquired the premises formerly oooupied by the Gas Company in Cherif Pasha-street for its head offices. The development of the com-pany's business rendered a change of premises necessary, and there is no doubt that with the forthcoming increase of its capital the Comptoir will occupy an important position among the credit establishments of our city.
New Carman Church In Cairo.

The scheme for the erection of a new church and school for the German Evangelical community in Cairo is progressing favourably. Already several meetings of the leading members of the colony have been held, and at the last M. Mefz, church-warden, read a report on the sale ot the present buildings and the pur- chase of the land at Boulae on which the new premises are to be built. The German Consol heartily approved of the operations. The Pastor proposes building a church for three or four hundred people, and a school with baths, refectories, and accommodations for the faculty. This scheme would leave a surplus of land which could be sold or rented according to circumstances.
The Egyptian Ostende.

It is fortunate that whilst every one does their utmost to provide for the wants and comfort of our winter guests, there is at least one hotel proprietor who does not forget the jaded official and business man whose work keeps him in Egypt throughout the summer months. Visitors to the Saan Stefano Casino next summer will be agreeably surprised at the enormus alterations that are being made there; the hotel, whilst being greatly enlarged, being practically re-built, and we understand that ahoot £50,000 is to be expended on it. The work has been placed in the hands of the Egyptian Constructions, Limited, who have undertaken to have the building ready for the reception of guests in April next, and this will mesh a particularly smart piece of work.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR
div.p: RESTORATION OF THE ESCUTCHEON.
AN IMPOSING CEREMONY

This morning the ceremony took place of replacing the Imperial coat of arms which was torn down from its position over the door of the Russian Consulate at Alexandria by the mob yesterday week. Shortly after 10 o'o'ock the Snb-Governor of Alexandria, Mo- hamed Bey Hafiz (in lieu of Mustapha Pasha Ibadi) the Governor, who is indisposed, arrived at the Russian Consulate, in full uniform, in order to represent the Egyptian Government at the ceremony. Among the officials present were Miralai Hopkinson Bey. Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, and Kaimakam Cobbe Bey the Sub-Commandant. The Guard Company and the Police Band were drawn up in the Ramleh Boulevard in front of the Consulate. All traffic was stopped, but there was not a great crowd of spectators present as it wan not generally known that the ceremony would take place this morning.

M. A. N. d'Ahezi. the Imperial Russian Consul at Alexandria, took up his position in front of the Consulate in company with M. H. de Bach, the Russian Vice Consul, M. Antoine Hamaoui, the chancellor of the Consolate, and M. Z-ky Pharaon, the dragoman. The Imperial esoutoheon, which had been repainted and regilded after the contumelious treatment it had received at the hands of the mob, was then hoisted to its former position over the entrace to the Consulate. The Russian flag was flown over the Consulate, the Guard Company presented arms, and the Police Band played the Imperial Russian Anthem, while all the staff of the Russian consulate and the Egyptian officials present sainted. The Russian Consul then shook hands with Mohamed Bey Hafez and there was a general interchange of greetings between the Consular staff and the Egyptian officials. The band then played the Khedivial Hymn, the Imperial coat-of arms was finally adjusted, and amidst another exchange of official handshakes the interesting function was brought to a olose.
The crowd, which had considerably increased while the ceremony was in progress, preserved a most respectful demeanour, and made no demonstration of any sort

M. d'Abaza, the Russian Consol,accompanied by M. de Bach, the Vice-Consul, then drove to the Alexandira Gonvernorat, and oalled on the Sub-Governor, to thank him on behalf of the Russian Government for the courtesy of the Egyptian authorities in having attended the ceremony.
DEPARTURE OF PRISONERS

The these Russian subjects, Botsoff, Shureen, and Volpoula, left Port Said for Odessa late on Saturday night. They were put upon a special train from Alexandria at Hadra station and, accompanied by police and an escort from the Russian Consulate here, they were taken to, Port Said, where they were embarked on a Russian steamer. The special train was ran direct from Hadra to Port Said without changing. An officer of the Alexandria City Police and twenty Russian detectives were also on the train.
THE POLICE CHARGES

The only charge brought by the authorities of the Alexandria Government against any British aubject is that against Mr. William Patrick Foley. This man will ba tried as soon as the summons is issued, which will be done on the application of the police authorities. The charges against the subjects of other Powers for taking part in tbe disorders have not yet been made ont, because it is first neccessary for the Egyptian authorities to draw ap "process-verbaux" in such cases, but this procedure is not needed in the case of a British subject, against whom it is only necessary to issue a summons.

div.head: PRINCE OF UDINA'S VISIT
div.p: The Prince of Udine, accompanied by Commandant Marengo, of the craiser Calabris, and the Marquis di Soragua, Italian Consul General at Alexandria paid a visit to the Alexandria branch of the Bank of Rome yesterday. His Royal Highness was recived by M. Giovani de Beaupuis, the manager of the Bank, who conducted the Prince over the establishment. The Prince expressed his satisfaction at the great progress which this important Italian hank has made since its Alexandria branch was started, and he complimented M. de Beaapuis on his most successful management. The Prinoe of Udina left Alexandria this morning in the Calabria for Venice where his voyage round the world on that man-of-war will end. He started from that port on his trip in February, 1905.
RESERACHERS AT DEIR EL BAHRI

In reference to a paragraph which appeared in our issue of the 23rd inst., concerning the researches now being conducted for the Egypt Exploration Fond at Deir el Bahri, Mr. James F. Dennis, assistant director at Deir el Bahri, writes to call our attention to the fact that "Mr. Hall is not connected in any way with our excavations this year. The work is in charge of Dr. Edouard Naville, assisted by Mr. C. F. Currelly, Mr. M. D. Dalison, and myself; we four form the entire staff"

div.head: THE HELOUAN SEASON
div.p: DANCE AT TEWFIK PLACE

The dance at the Tewfik Palaoe Hotel no Saturday night formed a very fitting conclusion to the enjoyable week of festivities at Helouan. The finals of the tennis tournament had been played off that morning, Mrs. Macintosch Walker and Mr. Tomlinson carrying everything before them; and in spite of the hard work of the last few days anrd nights everybody was in excellent form for the last event of the season. There was a large dinner party at the Grand that night at which Messrs. Gunter and Macnaghten presided; and the dining-room at the Tewfik has its full share of cheery parties preparatory to the danee. The programms was an excellent one and a most happy air of friendliness pervaded the precincts of the old palace, everybody knowing everybody, and all bent on enjoying themselves. To enumerate those who were present is but to recapitulate the names of those who also dance 1 through the cheery hours at the Grand on Thursday; and doubtless there will be other occasions in the future when the same merry band of Helousuites will meet again to revive their friendships. At the conclusion of the programme the tennis prizes were distributed in the hall, Miss Tottenham presenting them to the victors, and Mr. Tomlinson proposing a vote of thanks to the afore mentioned lady and to Mr. Sawyer, both of whom had been instrumental in organizing the sports. After tha distribution of prizes an adjournment was made in the direction of the supper room ; and though various more sober-minded of the guests took this opportanity to slip away quietly to their bedrooms, there were others who continued their festivities for some time longer; and strains of music penetrated the adjoining corridors till well into the early hours of the morning.

While on the subject of Helouan, mention must be made of the latest addition to the resources of the place in the shape of a delight-ful little chalet 'San Giovanni," which has been erected this season under the anspices of Mr. Springer of Al Hayat. This little cafe- restaurant is situated some two miles from Helouan on the very banks of the Nile and should prove a most delightfol object for an afternoon's drive or ride. It is approached by an excellent road for which thanks are mainly due to Hafez Effendi, that most energetic of inspectors who has already performed wonders in Helouan, and who doubtless will do much more to win the gratitude of the inhabitants. The chalet is a pretty building surrounded by a garden, and has a wide verandah running roand it. Inside it there are dainty tea and reading rooms, while while flat roof spaces as well as the verandahs have also been provided with chairs and tea tables.lt is indeed a delightful little retreat and should be in great quest especially in the warmer weather. The view across the river is perfect; and the arrangements and buildings are as complete and dainty as Mr. Springer knows how to make them. For the convenience of people wishing to visit the cafe, a motor serivice has been instituted, the cars starting from the railway station upon the arrival the trains ; and through "San Giovanni" has only been open for a few short weeks, and the weather has not proved kind to al-fresco meals during that period, people are already finding their way down there in increasing numbers.

div.head: HELOUAN BATHS
div.p: Of the various improvements made recently in the celebrated Halouan Bathing Establishment none has been more effective than the heating apparatus which has been installed this year. The old system with its wasteful boilers has now been superseded by a modern hot steam apparatus which not only provides a genial glow over the various rooms and passages of the establishment, but which also supplies heat to the sulphar baths with wonderfal regularity and expedition. Thus in under five minutes the contents of a large bath can be heated to 102° Fahr. with little or no loss of its medicinal qualities; and the heat can be regulated and maintained in a manner impossible under the old system.

These powerful sulphur springs of Helouan have been in use from time immemorial, and are still said to be the finest palliative for all rheumatic and gouty complaints. Under the control of the Government the baths have been equipped with all the latest modern improvements and now compare with those of the best known thermal establishments of Europe. There are separate wings given over to the use of ladies and gentlemen respectively, each containing, in addition to the ordinary large baths in private rooms, various other baths for special purposes. There are the special Helouan sulphur baths in which the patient is massaged by two attendants while lying immersed by the water; there are the new Vichu baths for toning and bracing up the system, the patient lying on india-rubber cushions while needle sprays of water, hot or cold, fall from long pipes overhead; and there are the electric light baths where the patient its within a cabinet lined with over forty electric lights of twenty-five rcandle pewer each. There are also large unroofed swimming baths in the rear of the establishment where the milky white water is somehwere foot deep, and these are well patronized during warmer weather. Dr. Hobson has his consulting rooms within the establishment and there is a staff of competent r u ses and masseurs to carry out the treatment, the services of two female and four male attendants from Harrogate being requisitioned during the season. At the present moment over 100 baths are taken daily on an average ; and every year sees an addition in the number of the patients who derive benefit

from these wonderful waters. The action of the sulphur contained therein is incredible; it tarnishes and corrodes the metal forments of the baths almost as soon as it comes in touch with them, and nothing has yet been discovered to withstand it. However scrupulously clean the baths are kept the enamel is very quickly discoloured by it; and where tiles or bricks are used the surface becomes eaten away in a remarkably short space of time. The wear and tear is consequently very high no pains nor expense are spared to keep the bath and arrangements in as good a condition as possible.

div.head: KAISER'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: REJOICINGS IN EGYPT

At Berlin, on January 27, 1859, the Kaiser was born, and yesterday, the anniversary of his birthday, was most loyally celebrated by German subjects throughout Egypt. A special thanksgiving service was he'd at ten o'clock, in the German Protestant Church, in the presence of the German Consul and staff, and the Italian and Austro-Hoagarian Consuls, An official reception was held at the consulate at 11 o'clock which was largely attended. At midday the Krieg Verein Club gave an entertainment at the Swisz Beer Hall, and in the evening there was a great kommers at the Effel Tower Music Hall.

In Cairo, the Imperial anniversary was marked with the customary official and religious ceremonial. A Te Deum was sung at ten o'clock in the German Church, after which Count Bernadonff received the colony at the Agency. In the afternoon, Count and Countess Bernsdonff and the stuff of the Agency and Consulate were present at the treat at the German Sohool. The evening's festivities included a banquet and a family gathering.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: PRECEDENT FOR MANILA.

Washington, January 6.— There is much reason to believe that the issuance of the report of the Bureau of Insular Affairs upon the Agricultural Bank of Egypt will have little influence upon the Senate committee having that matter in charge. The bill introduced by Senator Lodge last spring was hung up in the Senate committee on the Philippines by a very decided majority of members, none of whom, according to recent inqury, have shown any change of position.

The bill provides that a guaranty shall be made to the company with headquarters in Manila of an income not exceeding 4 per cent, per annum upon cash capital actually invested in such agricultural bank. The loans are limited to $ 5,000 in any one sum, the interest charge limited to 10 per cent, and no loans shall be made except for the purpose of assisting agri- culture in the Philippine Islands.

The special agent appointed by the Bnrean to investigate the operation of the Agricultural Bank in Egypt reports most favourably as to result, and is of the opinion that similar results might be expected in the Philippines, though in a less degree successful. He points out that in all the years of its operations the Government has never been obliged to advance the guarantee.

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS
div.p: Mr. Zaphiris Matzas, the successor of the late Mr. John Pezmazaglon in the management of the Bank of Athens, is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday next from the Pinaens. He intends to inspect all the branchs of the Bank of Athens throughout Egypt. He will afterwards proceed to Marseilles to continue the negotiations, begun by the late manager, for founding a branch of the Bank of Athens in that city.

div.head: ZIZNIA THEATRE.
div.p: Saturday's performance of "Lohengrin" did not come up to our expectations, but, to be Irish, we never expected that it would. It was not for want of pains being taken; all worked with sea and seemed surprisingly satisfied with the result. Nevertheless its conception was very far from meeting requirements. It was hard to discover much of the solemn and ethereal harmonies of the Holy Grail, the "symbol of the supra sensual," amid the almost light-hearted deportment of the orchestra and flaccid sentimentalityy of the performers. The mystic was constantly being sacrificed to the romantic, with a result as unhappy as it was unintelligible. No doabt allowance mast be made for the drama being given in Italian by artiste, whose capabilities are foreign to anything Wagnerian, and before a housee which delights in emitting "bravos" at odd moments and in applauding vooal gym-nasties; but these considerations are hardly sufficient to justify the inadeguate manner in which the work was grasped. Since we have a good all-round opera company this season, it seems a pity that they should try to exceed their limtations when there is so wide a choice within their scope. We are tempted to a Johnsonian reminder: "A cow is a very good animal in the field, but we turn her out of a garden."

div.head: STEARMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner City of Oxford arrived here on Saturday last from Liverpool and Malta with passengers and a general cargo. The Elllerman liner Fabian sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday last for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head: K.S.C
div.p: JUNIOR CHAMIONSHIP POLO TOURNAMENT

The K.S.C. team and the Coldstream Guards team No. I were left in for the final. With any lack the Coldstream Guards would have won, and on the whole they had the best of the game, but they missed their goals, and Mr. Aldam, with a strained arm, was of no use to his side. Mr. Bentinck and Mr. Gibbs played a very good game, showing judgment and skill. And the improvement of the play-of the team in the last two months is most marked, their combination being decidedly good. For the winners, Capt. Bartlett was a host in himself; he kept his team in fairly good order, and they all did their share of the work.
Warmer weather and the Inniskilling Dragocn baud added to the attractions of the afternoon, many spectators being present to witness the final.Mrs. Bullcok very kindly gave away the prize.Teams:—.

First Chukker. The Coldstreams got away from the throw-in, and scored a goal in the first two minutes of the game. This put the K.S.C. on their metal. After attackirg for the rest of the chukker. Capt. Bartlett scored a goal for them just as the bell rang. Score: One al1.
2nd Chukker. The game was very fast and keenly contested, the Coldstream Guards having decidedly the best of it, but just failing to soore

3rd Chukker. Capt. Bartlett made a brilliant ran up the ground, and well backed up by Mr. Hadow, scored a goal for the K.S.C., and shortly afterwards yet another was soored by the same player, the score being 3 to 1 in favour of the K.S.C. team. The Coldstream Guards then forced the game, making great efforts to score, but had no luck, their shots at goal always just failing.
4th Chukker. A brilliant run by Capt. Bartlett and another by Mr. Bantinck were the feature of the chukker. They both, however, failed in their shot at goal.
5lh Chukker. Play was fast and keen. Capt Kennedy made a fine run up the ground, the ball going behind; then the bell rang, the KS.C. thus winning by 3 goals to 1.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—I have read with much interest in your issue of yesterday a letter written by 'A Casual Visitor" on the above subject. He points out the fact that Belgian joists have been employed in the construction, and that the quantity used is about 10,000 tons, a truly noble quantity tor a building of its size. Secondly, he says that the college was called into existence by British enterprise and generosity to commemorate our late Queen Victoria, and complains that the building specifioatiou did not call for British material. I have been in the building business for a number of years, both in this country and in England, and have bought in my time large quantities of Belgian and English joists, and my experiance has taught me that for ordinary building work and such purposes as floors aud ceilings, etc., which is the purpose for which they are required in this instance, Belgian joists art quite good enough, although their ultimate breaking strain might be somewhat lower than that of British joists of similar section. As a set off against this, however, there is a difference of price, the difference being as a role about £2 per ton c.i.f. Alexandria in favour of the Belgian joist, so that, according to 'A Casual Visitor'*" estimate of the quantities, the committee of the Victoria College may at least congratulate themselves on having saved in 10,000 tons of joists a magnificent sum of about £20,000, which sum it is hoped will be need in furthering the education of the pupils at the college, which might otherwise have been spent in profits to the rolling mills where the British joists wotld have been made. The British Chamber of Commerce can hardly be expected to have very much power in influening the letting of such a contract for joists unless it can induce the British manufacturers to arrive a good deal nearer the mark as regards price, for it is well known among engineers that for ordinary structural work the Continental joist is as suitable as, and far cheaper than the British, although I am willing to admit that, for special purposes, the latter area more reliable. In my opinion the 10,000 tons is rather a full estimate of the quantities ; probably 300 or 400 tons would be nearer the mark.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Mansfield de C Findlay, first secretary at the British Agency, and Mrs. de Findley have returned to Cairo from their three mouths, holiday in England.
Count M anzoni, first secretary of the Italian Diplomatic Agency at Cairo, who has been transferred as Minister Pilenpotentiary at Athens, left yesterday for Rome by the Brindisi mail boat.
The marriage took place at Alexandira on Saturday of Mr. Max Stross to Mile. Pierra Lavaggi, daughter of Mine. Matilde Odero Vve. Lavaggi.

Sir Hamilton Lang, ex-Governor of the Daira Sanieh, Commindant Berger, of the Ottoman Public Debt, M. Lagoux, M Thearnauer, and last, but not least, Sir Ernest Cassel are among the leading members of the world of business and finance who are now among us.

We greatly regret to report the death of Mme. Gubran Bey Muscat wife of the wellknown chief of the Public Security Service at Cairo. At the funeral, which took place on Saturday afternoon, a multitude of the Bey's friends testified their sympathy by their presence.

Professor Dr. Henry Fairfield Osborne, director of the American Museum of Natural History, has arrived on a scientific mission at Cairo, bearing a large number of letters of introduction to the Geological Society. The professor and his party are staying Shepheard's Hotel, where they occupy the famous apartment recently vacated by H.R.H. the Duke Georg Wilhelm of Braunsohweig-Lnenebnrg.

div.head:
THE GERMAN ELECTIONS.
VICTORY OVER SOCIALISTS.
EXCITEMENT IN BERLIN.

div.p: (Midnight) The results of the polling for 53 seats are known : 19 second ballots will be necessary. The Socialists are the chief losers.

It is estimated that they have lost 18 seats and retained 5 in the Capital, but failed in the desperate assault on the so-called "Emperor's Division," where the second ballot is expected to result in the re-election of a Radical member.

The Emperor received batches of the results at the Palace. The city is unusually excited. A crowd watching the results exhibited on a screen at a newspaper office after the announcement of the Socialist losses, marched in procession to Prince von Bulow's palace singing the national anthem.

The Prince appeared in the courtyard. Speaking behind locked gates he quoted Bismarck's remark that once the German people had succeeded in putting the saddle on the horse they would soon be able to ride. He said that Germany to-day had shown they ware still able to ride: the whole world will recognise that the German people have a firm seat and overthrow everything opposing their welfare and greatness. (Reuter)

The last returns show the Socialist losses up to the present number 13 seats, but it is expected that they will lose still further in the seoond ballots. The Centrists are holding the ground. The Conservatives are gaining. A Government majority seems certain. The great feature of the Socialist losses is that they have occured in centres, such as Lepizg, Magdebourg, and Breelau. (Reuter)

Political circles are surprised at the greatness of the victory over the Socialists. Several large towns regarded as faithful to the Socialist party, such as Liepzig , Koenigsberg, Breslau, and the industrial centres of Saxe and Thuringe, have a ready declared in favour of the National party. Demonstrations have taken place before the Imperial Castle and the Palace of the Crown Prince. The results already known prove that the object of the dissolution of the Reichstag has been attained. (Reuter)

The results of the elections have given 257 elected and 160 second ballots. The following have been returned : 89 Deputies of the Centre, 29 Socialists, 41 Conservatives, 20 National Liberals, 10 of the Empire Party, 18 Poles, 80 various. The Socialists lose 19 seats. Havas

Out of 397 seats, the Centre has gained 89, Conservatives 41, Sooialists 29, National Liberals 20, and the other groups 58. The Socialist losses amount to 19 seats. There will be 160 second ballots and in 92 Socialists are standing. Everything now depends opon the Centre. If it supports the Sooialists the latter will regain the lost ground.

The city is illuminated and decorated with royal devices. Prince von Bulow and Count de Posadowsky condemn the police's rough handling of the patriotic crowd on Friday night, when they prevented it from going to the Emperor's Palace. An enquiry has been opened.
The Chief of the Police, in the course of an interview, stated that the prohibited the demonstration because he did not wish the Emperor's sleep to be disturbed. (Reuter)
The Emperor, on the occasion of his birthday announced that the punishment for lese-majeste would heuceforth be coufiued to premeditated malevolent cases. (Reuter)
The Kaiser's birthday was enthusiastically celebrated to day. (Havas)

div.head:
SERVIAN UNREST.
EXPLOSION IN CROWN PRINCE'S ROOMS.

div.p: A quantity of gunpowder and cartridges exploded in the apartments of the Crown Princs. The windows were shattered. No one was injured. (Reuter)
The Russian evacuation of Manchuria has produced a most favorable impression in European Foreign Offices as well as in Japanese Embassies. (Reuter)
Of the delegates elected ot the first degree for the Duma, 500 are of the Right, 458 Moderates, 238 Socialists, and 35 cadets (H.)

Army Surgeon Doen has submitted to the Imperial Medical Sooiety a new anti toxine treatment for dysentery. It consists of serum obtained from the inoculation of rabbits. He claims that soldiers have been treated successfully. (Reuter)

The noted English motorist, Mr. Marrioff, competing on the Ormonde Beach (Florida) has been the victim of an accident. Whilst travelling at 125 miles an hour his car struck an inequality on the beach and turned a somersault three times. Mr. Marriott was taken up unconscious. An eye is gone, and a rib broken. (Reuter)

div.head: N. D. L STEAMER ON FIRE.

div.p: The Admiralty reports that the cruiser Diadem found the Norddeutscher Lloyd steamer Seydlifz, bound from Penang f or Colombo, on fire. She embarked 105 passengers and the mails and escorted the Seydlitz to Point de Galle. The forepart of the vessel has been burnt out. (Reuter)
Mr. Whiteley's murderer is improving. His name is Rayner. He is no relation whatever of Mr.Whiteley, and wass apparently unknown to him. (Reuter)

div.p: The balance-sheet of this company for the year ended on the 30th September, 1906, shows a net profit amounting to L.E. 3,897.619 m/m. This sum represents the results of the working of the factories of the company since the profit derived from the sale of the five feddans belonging to the company was partly employed in redeeming the following Items of assets :
Machinery and Installations …..... 18,035
Tubes and Robbins.….…....120
Preliminary expenses ..............…...2,289

The above sum of L.E. 2,289 profits brought forward from last year, and has been employed in the total redemption of the "Preliminary Expenses" account. The figure of LE. 3,897 could then be considered as the first benefits which would enable the company to pay a dividend, but the board of directors deemed it more prudent to carry forward the above sum, and to await the results of the following year before making a distribution of dividend. The effect of this decision will be to consolidate the present situation of the company, which is already satisfactory, and to lower the estimation of its stocks.

The present board ot the company consists of: Messrs. J.Rolo (chairman), Eugene Debourr, Baron J. de Menaces. E Nahman, M. Salvago, A. Suarez, C. de Tschidi, and G. Zervudachi. The capital of the company amounts to £150 000 divided into 148,500. Ordinary shares of £1 each, fully paid, and 6,000 D.ferred shares of 5 shillings each, fully paid. According to the statutes, the profits of the company are to be distributed in the following manner : After first setting aside 5 % for the Ordinary shares, the balance is to be divided as follows : 5 % to the directors, 25 % to the Deferred shareholders, and 70% to the Ordinary shareholders.

It is interesting to recall the fact that at the time of issure, the shares of the company had reached a very high figure, but that after the unsatisfactory results of the first year's working, the shares fell from £2.10 to £1.5 0. We give below the fluctuations which have taken place in the quotations of Spinning shares since 1899 :

The present qutation is 3/4, but we think this is abnormally low, considering the satisfactory results which may be expected in the future, and the nominal price, ie., £1, does not seem to us to be too high for the present. div.head: THE MYSTERY OF CLEOPATRA.
div.p: MR. TREE'S PLAY REVIVES AN OLD CONTROVERSY.

According to Pascal, the size of Cleopatra's nose influenced the course of the world's history. Now, apropos of Mr. Tree's production at His Majesty's, controversy again rages around the personality of the Alexandrian Queen, her ancestry, her style of dress and living, even the colour of her eyes and complexion. Mr. Edwyn Bevan, in a letter in , ''The Times," criticises the archaeological aspect of Mr. Tree's production. He sweepingly asserts that in the matter of the historical correctness of scenery and costume the play "is false not in this or that detail, but , radically io its whole conception."

Commenting upon this statement, Mr. Percy Macquoid, who, in collaboration with Mr. Comyns Carr and Mr. Tree, is responsible for , the production, told a member of the "Daily News" staff that the Court of Cleopatra was Grecco-Egyptian, and by no means pure Egyptian.

"In the notes prefacing the programme of the play at His Majesty's," he said, "it is further stated that it has been thought advisable, in the mounting of the production, to eliminate the Greek feeling that existed. And it is perfectly certain by reference to the mummy cases and statuettes of the period that Egyptian art, although then in its decadence, was still conservative."
"Can yon mention any other authority on this point?" asked the representative.

''Well, Henry Housaaye, an acknowledged authority on the subject, assert that every where in the decoration of the Ptolemies' surroundings the local colouring of Egypt was introduced. It would be wise, I think, for. Mr. Bevan, before he makes the assertion that Mr. Tree's production 'is false, not in this or that detail, but radically in the whole conception,' to quote some authority besides his own, to the effect that Cleopatra did not inhibit a palace built by one ot her ancestors. To this descent our critic refers, as being pure Greek, with the exception of 'a very remote Persian ancestress.' The historical fact, however.is that the lady in question was Cleopatra, a princess of Coele Syria and Palestine, who married Ptolemy V. in 193 B.C., that is, some 130 years before the birth of Shakespeare's heroine."
"And what of the assertion that there is no single instance of a marriage between a Ptolemaic prince and a native Egyptian ?"

"We never made such a statement," was the reply; "but it wonld be presumed that Mr. Bevan knows the state of confusion and demoralisation that existed at the Alexandria Court between the reign of Ptolemy VI and Ptolemy XIII. This is what Professor Mahaffy says on the subject: 'We have now reached the moment when the history of Egypt under the Macedonian dynasty declines in dignity and increases in complication. Hitherto, though it was usual to associate the Queen or the Prince Royal in the government, there is no doubt about the reigining King. From henceforth we have almost constantly rival brothers, asserting themselves in turn Queen-Mothers controlling their King sons—internecine fends and bloodshed in the Royal house—till the stormy end of the dynasty with the daring Cleopatra VI. The historian is bound to chronicle these wretched complications, to unravel these problems of chronology, and yet they only affect the reigning house, and tell us nothing of interest to posterity. We must have recourse to private papers, journals, cx'rac's of obscure persons, bills of stewards, and lists of tax gathers, to learn something of the gradual relapse of the country from Hellenism into the ineradicable Egypt of the native race."
CLEOPATRA'S APPEARANCE.

"Do not Professor Mahaffy's views thus corroborate your own statement that the incidental accidents of marriage had materially affected the personal appearanoe, tastes, and manners of the later Ptolemies ?"

"The incidental accidents of marriage mentioned, on which Mr. Bevan lays so great a stress," replied Mr. Macquoid, "do not always refer to legitimate accidents. And the proclivites and character of our own British Solomon, James I., by no means point to our national characteristics. The appearance of Cleopatra on the coins of the period and in the bust at the British Museum is typically Semitic, and pieces of Egyptian furniture of the last century before Christ, although termed Greeco Egyptian, are distinctly more Egyptian than Greek.

"To open a controversy on the subject," concluded Mr. Marquoid, "is to my mind perfectly useless, as the producers of the play were as well inforned as Mr. Bevan is of the existence of Greek, and also Roman, taste at the Court of Cleopatra. Finally, to quote our critic's well-known statement, the very fact that 'Celopatra liked to be named the new Isis, and on State occasions appeared in the garb of the native goddess,' demonstrates how desirous she was of identifying her personality and her immediate surroundings with the country she ruled."

div.head: A TIME OF TROUBLE.
div.p: Woman's Woes at Middle Life,
Fainting Dizzy Wdneak.
Aching Back and Weary Limbs.
A Sunderland Lady in Despair.
Finds a New Lease of Life,
Comfort, Health and Strength in
DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

"I felt that 1 was going altogether wrong in health three years ago, and what I subsequently suffered only those of my own sex can appreciate. Yet today, at 43 years of age, I am well, bright and energetic, and the constant wonder and envy of many women. And to all I say that the credit of this great change in me is due in every way to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. They alone reward me when I was passing through the time of trouble that women of middle age have to face, and I know how valuable and helpful they are at such a crisis."
These words uttered by Mrs. Elizabeth Campbell, of 18. Silver-screet, Sunderland, convey a world of meaning to the countless women who countinue to suffer in silence with little or no hope of relief.

"The first warning I received of impending trouble," saif Mrs. Campbell, "was a strange dizziness at time, will sudden flushes, feelinghot and cold in turn. Then something like cold settled on me. I felt weak and lazy, with a tight feeling across the chest and a difficulty in breathing. My heart felt as though it was labouring under a heavy load. At night I would break oat in perspiration and feel as if the I room was stifling me yet perhaps the next hour I would become quite cold, especially my feet, and shiver with a chill down my back, which ached with a dull, gnawing pain that took all my strength away. Frequently the dizziness attacked me if walking upstairs or when in the street. One morning, when making a cup of tea, I fell forward in a fainting fit, and narrowly escaped falling into the fire. I received a terrible shock; for days doctors were in constant attendance. I fell away, so weak and thin that my life was despaired of.

"Still I lingered on - one day a little better, the next day worse—when one afternoon a violent spasm shot down my back, through my legs, like stabs of burning knives. Doctors said that sciatica had developed, and I no doubt got the poisons og this in my system through being out in bad weather. With this new trouble on top of all my previoos sufferings medicine seemed quite useless to me.

"A good friend called and recommended Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, and I then remembered how often this medicine was praised by women. I sent for a box and I began taking the pills. Before long I felt that I was on the mend.

"So I continued the pills, determined not to give up taking them until I was cured. My appetite picked up and I could take food and digest it. I rallied steadily and felt a good circulation in my veins. My head became clear and free from dizziness, while I had no pains in my back. div.head: MORTGAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: DR. EID'S REPORT.
(Second Notice.)

For the mortgage debts contracted with institutions other than the five already mentioned, the best information that can be gleaned is the total amount lent, and as for private dealings these must for ever remain an unknown or at least a very uncertain quantity. The total amount lent by companies (chiefly English insurancee companies) Dr. Eid palces at L.E. 1,400,000, and be adds a further L.E. 800,000 for private transactions (which figure, we must admit, we think to be a distinct under-estimation),making in all L E. 2,200,000. For this it is impossible to obtain the exact number of loans, and in consequence the average amount of a loan cannot be stated.

This much, however, is possible, and this the energy of Dr. Eid has accomplished. The number ot loans made by the banks is known, as is the number registered at the Greffes, and the difference gives approximately the number of loans contracted otherwise than with the banks. Dr. Eid sets out these figures in two columns for the last six years, and in lookirg at this table we see the following : —

Assuredly the striking increase of these figures muat speak for itself. Striking, however, though it is, it need give rise to no alarm, for it is both natural and justifiable, and as, Dr. Eld shows us later, is a testimony of the increasing wealth of the country. Of course the introduction of the Agricultural Bank in 1903 with its facilities for small loans has had much to do with the numerical increase of the mortgages, and it may be safely asserted that each advance made by this institution is a direct blow, as we said before, at the almost criminal extortion of the village usurer and in inverse proportion a corresponding benefit to the fellah directly, and indirectly to the country as a whole. But another cause also has been recently at work whereby the number of private mortgages has been so markedly reduced,and that is the extraordinarily rapid rise in the last year or two in the price of town and building property. In place of advancing money to a mortgager whereby the mortgager, by investing the same in town land, acquired a comparative fortune in a very short time, every capitalist h s entered the field as a buyer of property, and few private capitalists to-day are content with the average investment of a sound mortgage, but all spare money is now employed in the purchase of land wish a view to a rapid rise and the re-sale thereof.

But to return once more to figures. The actual number of mortgages contacted is by itself of little value. We must also have the superficial area of the agricultural land of the country and the average amount of each mortgage : and the difficulty is to fix this average amount. To do this recourse most be had to the information if private persons, and although there may be the most competent, the recourse in a category of statistics is admittedly precarious, but the best obtainable under the circumstances. In the first place it must be recognised that private loans command a higher rate of interest, being frequently made through family relations and for other reasons of similar importance in the East where consideration or toleration plays so leading a part, considerations moreover which no bank —no mere corporation without a soul- could ever be expected to recognise.

Dr. Eid takes the mean amount of the mortgages advanced by the banks in 1905, namely, LE. 165, and to obtain a rough approximation of the average sum of a private transaction he doubles this L.E. 165, making it L.E. 330. At this figure he calculates the total of the mortgage indebtedness from private sources other than the five banks to reach the figure of L.E. 5,500,000 for the years 1902 to 1905. Previous to the year 1902 the wants of the

country were far more limited, but since that date the Entente Cordiale, the opening of ths Assouan Dam, the introduction of new banking and financial companies, and in particular the foundation ot the Agricultural Bank, have one and all given a tremendous impetus to financial and agricultural schemes, with the result that in 1903 the number of mortgages registered sprang from 16,000 to 37,000 in a twelve-month. And from 1902 to 1905, of mortgages property so called the sum total of indebtedness from all sources amounted to L.E. 28,245,000.

To conclude the subject of mortgages properly so-oalled, Dr. Eid has drawn up three most excellent tables showing respectively the classification of the various loans, the first according to their nature, town or country or urban and so forth ; the second according to their importance, that is, according to the amount of the loan, which varies from L.E. 1 to L E. 10,000, and the third and last according to the time of the duration of the mortgage ; tables too long to set out here in fall but well worth the careful perusal of one who finds a real interest in the subject

div.head: NAVY CONTRACTS.
div.p: PORT SAID AND SUEZ.

TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Sail and Suez for twelve months from 1st April 1907.
Each article should be tendered for separately, but the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm must be placed on the same Form.
Prices should be quoted in English currency.

Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate General, Port Said, to whom tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1907.
The Admiralty reserve the right of rejected all or any tenders, and of accepting any portion of a tender.
(Signed)D.A. Cameron,
Navy Agent. British Consulate General, Port Said.
19th January 1907.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: of the
"Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette," is published a midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhausteive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various maarket fluctuations, and the copies of the official of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for a yead abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
